channel.title: Sustainability News@Emory
channel.description: All the latest news from Emory University.

item.title: John Grade to Build Biodegradable Sculptures in Atlanta
item.description: Environmental artist John Grade comes to Atlanta as an Emory University artist-in-residence Nov. 6-19 to design and build large-scale sculptural installations using biodegradable materials.

item.title: Celebrating the West African Yam Harvest With Atlanta's Culinary Masters
item.description: This fall, as part of the special exhibition programming for "Divine Intervention: African Art and Religion," the Michael C. Carlos Museum and Emory Dining and Sustainability Initiatives celebrate the African yam and the Georgia sweet potato harvest.

item.title: Emory Village Completes Its New Look
item.description: The planting of 50 trees and shaping of a pocket park this fall will complete the 10-year-in-the-making revitalization of Emory Village.

item.title: Emory Rated Gold in National AASHE Sustainability Assessment
item.description: Emory University has received a "Gold" rating in the Sustainability Tracking, Assessment and Rating System for its leadership and innovation in university sustainability.

item.title: Clifton Corridor Transit Project at Crucial Juncture
item.description: Emory leaders are pushing to keep alive a proposed new transit line linking Clifton Road and MARTA's Lindbergh station.

item.title: Construction Begins for New Health Sciences Research Building
item.description: Construction of a new Health Sciences Research Building on the Emory University campus kicked off with an official groundbreaking on June 15.

item.title: Emory's Top Leader to Receive NASPA President's Award
item.description: Emory University President James W. Wagner has been selected to receive the President's Award of the National Association of Student Personnel Administrators for Region III.

item.title: Emory Named to National "Honor Roll" for Commitment to Service
item.description: Emory University recently earned national kudos for its commitment to the greater good through research and service. The university has been named to the 2010 President's Higher Education Community Service Honor Roll.
